title: 103_hr4759
content: The Act may be cited as the "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994". The Congress recognizes the Department of Energy's contributions to math and science education, the need for collaboration between agencies and educators, the importance of outstanding teachers in the education community, and the effectiveness of pilot programs in improving education. The Congress acknowledges the importance of outstanding elementary and secondary school mathematics and science teachers in improving education programs. A pilot program has shown the effectiveness of having these teachers serve in professional staff capacities in the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Act establishes a national fellowship program for exceptional math and science teachers, known as "Albert Einstein Fellows". The Act defines key terms such as "contractor" as a nonprofit educational organization administering the fellowship program, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Energy, "elementary school" and "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "outstanding" in relation to math or science teachers who have won the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching. The Education Act of 1965 defines the term "outstanding" for math or science teachers who have received national or state recognition and have taken a sabbatical leave to participate in a fellowship program under the Act. The term "secondary school" is defined as per the Education Act of 1965, and it applies to teachers who have taken a sabbatical leave to participate in a fellowship program under the Act. The Education Act of 1965 defines "secondary school" for teachers on sabbatical leave to join a fellowship program authorized by Section 5. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program allows the Secretary to provide fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers. The number of fellowships awarded may be reduced based on available funding, with priority given to awarding them. The Secretary may reduce the number of fellowships awarded based on funding availability, with priority given to outstanding math or science teachers. Fellowships are provided to teachers in the Senate, House of Representatives, and other specified locations. The Act provides fellowships for outstanding math or science teachers in various government departments and agencies for a 10-month period. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program provides 10-month fellowships for exceptional math or science teachers in government departments and agencies. The program is administered by a contractor appointed by the Secretary, who oversees the application process and publication of program information. The contractor administers the Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program, including developing and administering the application process, screening applicants, and inviting applications from teachers in various recognition programs. The contractor administers the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program, including screening applicants and selecting recipients, organizing orientation, and implementing a reporting and evaluation program. The contractor administers the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program, including screening applicants, selecting recipients, organizing orientation, implementing a reporting and evaluation program, submitting annual reports to the Secretary, and managing all funds received under the Act. Final selections are made in Washington, D.C., after an initial screening process, with announcements made before May 1 for each fellowship term. The final selections for the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program are made in Washington, D.C. before May 1 for each fellowship term. The Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, Minority Leader of the Senate, and Secretaries of Energy are involved in selecting fellowship recipients for assignments in the House of Representatives and Senate. The Albert Einstein Fellowship Program involves selecting fellowship recipients for assignments in the House of Representatives and Senate, as well as various government departments and agencies. Each selected individual will be placed within the department, agency, institute, or office that the selector administers. Each fellowship recipient will be paid at a rate not exceeding the minimum annual rate for a GS-13 position. $550,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1995, with additional funding for fiscal years 1996 through 2001 to support the program.
